citations.narrative:
***Throughout the facility, there were at least six enclosures containing birds that were constructed where the public could
stand next to the enclosure. There were openings large enough in the enclosure walls that adult fingers, hands and arms
could be placed into the enclosures in close proximity to the birds.
No barriers or attendants were in these areas to ensure the safety of the animals or the public.
Enclosures that are constructed as to allow public to touch inside the enclosure, increases the risk of injury to the public or
the animals.
The licensee must construct the enclosures to restrict human contact, place barriers or provide attendants in these areas
and ensure that all enclosures provide safety for the animals and the public at all times during exhibition.
To be corrected by September 20, 2023

citations.desc: Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control.
citations.narrative:
***In the Roof Aviary area, a multitude of small black ants were observed coming through cracks in the wall and moving in
a line several feet across an adjacent wire enclosure wall where they disappeared inside an enclosure housing three
Golden Tamarins.
In the 1901 Breeding Aviaries, a multitude of small black ants were observed crawling across the wire cage walls and into
an enclosure (Lek 2), housing two pygmy marmosets, one of which was a baby.
Pests carry diseases which increases the risks of contamination and disease to the primates.
The licensee must ensure that the pest control program is effective to reduce contamination by pests in animal areas as
required.
Correct by 9/20/23

***In the Hawk-Headed Parrot enclosure, there was a screw head protruding out of the top of the housing unit,
approximately one inch, where the parrots had chewed the wood.
***In the Golden Headed Lion Tamarin Exhibit area, there was one enclosure that contained a Blue-banded Toucanet.
The log perches in this enclosure had two screw heads that protruded out of the log approximately one inch.
Sharp points & jagged edges can cause injury to the birds.
The licensee must remove or insert the screws and ensure that that enclosures are free of sharp points and jagged edges
as required.
To be corrected by September 20, 2023.

***Throughout the facility, there were at least five enclosures that had detached, torn and frayed shade cloth, exposed
heaters, thermometer and cords. Although the heaters were not being used during the inspection, the birds were sitting on
top of the metal heater covers. When heaters are used, the metal could be too hot for the birds to perch on.
Torn material, cords and exposed heating devices can contribute to entanglement or injury to the birds.
The licensee must remove, replace or repair and maintain these areas to protect the birds from injury as required.
To be corrected by September 28, 2023

***The enclosure that housed 17 flamingos was set up as an island like area. On one side of the enclosure, a short raised
barrier separated the flamingo area from a drop several feet down to a large shark pool housing saw tooth sharks, brown
bonnet head sharks, and other species of large fish. The curator informed the inspectors that on rare occasions a
Flamingo will fall out of its enclosure into the shark pool. They remove the animal as soon as it is discovered and
according to the curator no animals have been killed due to this.
Areas that lack complete containment for animals can lead to intentional or accidental escape and injury to the animals.
The licensee must design and construct the Flamingo enclosure to ensure that the birds are contained securely.
To be corrected by September 28, 2023

citations.desc: Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control.
citations.narrative:
***Two rats were observed inside the following enclosures:
In the Rain Forest open area, a rat was observed climbing up foliage in an upper portion of the balcony area where it
disappeared from view after climbing up to a raised green bird food receptacle.
In the enclosure called Cotinga Corner a rat was observed on the ground, eating loose bird feed, in close vicinity to
several avian species.
Additionally, rodent excreta was observed in Cage #24 of what is referred to as 1901 Breeding Aviaries. These fecal
pellets were noted on the back of the water receptacle for a red fan parrot housed within.
Pests carry diseases which increases the risks of contamination and disease to the birds.
The licensee must ensure that the pest control program is effective to reduce contamination by pests in animal areas as
required.
Correct by 9/20/23
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with manager.
Additional Inspectors:
BRENTON COX, ANIMAL CARE INSPECTOR n

narrative:

species.common: LITTLE PENGUIN / BLUE PENGUIN / FAIRY PENGUIN
